author: yorickdowne
content: <@755590043632140352> There's some docs that <@866046126279884851> maintains about which clients do and don't work on RISC-V, here: <https://github.com/eth-educators/eth-docker/issues/1873>

author: yorickdowne
content: "Docs", ok, an ongoing discussion on a github issue <:harold:1019414542075297892>

author: yorickdowne
content: Nimbus/Geth works, others are in various states of "not quite yet", I think

author: yorickdowne
content: Besu works, but is held back by lack of CI - no github RISC-V runners. Though cloud-v and pictlab have some stuff

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: Geth works on riscv5? But only on 64 bit right?

author: potuz
content: Yeah I'm aware, many of the problems come from the basic assembly on the hashing library. An unfortunate series of events led Prysm to use a goassembly version, which when it went to production shipped with a pure Go fallback for not-supported processors. The older hashtree version does not have a fallback and it does not have assembly for Risc V. Nimbus fallsback to a different library. Prysm only has the goassembly version that should fallback nicely to Go, but I think the bazel tooling doesn't work with Risc V. I need to get a board or setup an emulator well to dig into this, but I honestly don't have time for any forseeable future

author: yorickdowne
content: Yeah time is the issue. You can get a free cloud board to test on at cloud-v or pictlab, but that still requires time to play with it

author: potuz
content: Oh I'm not aware of these things, what are they? they'll give me shell access with access to an assembler and running tests?

author: yorickdowne
content: And afaik there is now one board that can actually sync mainnet, but it's fiendishly hard to source. Most boards only have the oomph to sync a testnet

author: yorickdowne
content: I haven't tried them myself. https://cloud-v.co/ and https://github.com/plctlab/riscv-lab-access ... yes I assume you get a board with shell access so you can try your dev on there

author: yorickdowne
content: RISC-V hardware is currently not as performant as RK3588 (the ARM64 behind Orange Pi5+, Rock 5B(+), &c). RISC-V hardware is evolving. I think what haurog is trying to do is get the software ready, so that when there's hardware to sync mainnet, the software is already waiting: Tested on testnets

author: haurog
content: I am also discussing riscv in the uncatecorized channel with tersec: https://discord.com/channels/595666850260713488/595721451651465227/1351180168365998101
